resultingRecommendation.shortDescription: Fortezza ciphers are supported
resultingRecommendation.handlingRecommendation: Disable Fortezza cipher suites
resultingRecommendation.detailedDescription: Fortezza cipher suites were developed by NSA in the 90s. You should better get rid of Fortezza algorithms.

recommendation.shortDescription: Evaluates whether the TLS server supports SEED ciphers
recommendation.detailedDescription: SEED is a 128 bit block cipher developed by the KISA (Korea Information Security Agency) in 1998

recommendation.shortDescription: Evaluates whether the TLS server supports IDEA ciphers
recommendation.detailedDescription: IDEA (International Data Encryption Algorithm) is a block cipher. It uses a 128 bit key and operates on 64 bit blocks.

resultingRecommendation.shortDescription: IDEA ciphers are enabled
resultingRecommendation.handlingRecommendation: Disable IDEA ciphers

recommendation.shortDescription: Evaluates whether the TLS server supports RC2 ciphers
recommendation.detailedDescription: RC2 is a 64 bit block cipher designed by Ron Rivest in 1987

resultingRecommendation.handlingRecommendation: Disable RC2 ciphers

recommendation.shortDescription: Evaluates whether the TLS server supports RC4 ciphers
recommendation.detailedDescription: RC4 is a stream cipher designed by Ron Rivest in 1987

resultingRecommendation.shortDescription: RC4 ciphers are enabled
resultingRecommendation.handlingRecommendation: Disable RC4 ciphers

recommendation.shortDescription: Evaluates whether the TLS server supports CBC cipher suites

resultingRecommendation.shortDescription: CBC cipher suites are enabled
resultingRecommendation.handlingRecommendation: Disable CBC cipher suites

recommendation.shortDescription: Evaluates whether the TLS server supports AEAD (Authenticated Encryption with Associated Data) cipher suites, e.g., AES-GCM

resultingRecommendation.shortDescription: AEAD cipher suites are disabled
resultingRecommendation.handlingRecommendation: Enable AEAD cipher suites, e.g., AES-GCM

recommendation.shortDescription: Evaluates whether the TLS server supports Perfect Forward Secrecy (PFS)

resultingRecommendation.shortDescription: PFS is not supported
resultingRecommendation.handlingRecommendation: Enable perfect forward secure cipher suites, e.g., TLS-DHE or TLS-ECDHE

recommendation.shortName: Support for only PFS cipher suites
recommendation.shortDescription: Evaluates whether the TLS server exclusively supports Perfect Forward Secrecy (PFS)

resultingRecommendation.shortDescription: Not all cipher suites are perfect forward secure
resultingRecommendation.handlingRecommendation: Consider disabling cipher suites which are not perfect forward secure. Enable only perfect forward secure cipher suites, e.g., TLS-DHE or TLS-ECDHE

recommendation.shortDescription: Evaluates whether the TLS server prefers Perfect Forward Secrecy (PFS) cipher suites

resultingRecommendation.shortDescription: PFS cipher suites are not preferred
resultingRecommendation.handlingRecommendation: Enable cipher suite ordering and prefer PFS cipher suites

recommendation.shortDescription: Evaluates whether the TLS server enforces Perfect Forward Secrecy (PFS) cipher suites

resultingRecommendation.shortDescription: PFS cipher suites are not enforced
resultingRecommendation.handlingRecommendation: Enable cipher suite ordering and enforce PFS cipher suites

recommendation.shortDescription: Evaluates whether the TLS server supports AES cipher

resultingRecommendation.handlingRecommendation: Enable AES cipher suites

recommendation.shortDescription: Evaluates whether the TLS server supports token binding

recommendation.shortName: Support for session resumption with session tickets
recommendation.shortDescription: Evaluates whether the TLS server supports session resumption with session tickets

resultingRecommendation.shortDescription: Session tickets are disabled
resultingRecommendation.handlingRecommendation: Enable session resumption with session tickets

recommendation.shortName: Support for session resumption with session IDs
recommendation.shortDescription: Evaluates whether the TLS server supports session resumption with session IDs
Evaluates whether the TLS server supports session resumption with session tickets whose keys are being rotated
recommendation.detailedDescription: Session tickets are created with symmetric keys. The lifetime of the symmetric keys used for session tickets should be restricted to reduce the attack surface. The ticket lifetime is typically indicated in the ticket lifetime hint.

resultingRecommendation.shortDescription: Session resumption with rotating session tickets is disabled
resultingRecommendation.handlingRecommendation: Frequently changing session ticket keys improves the security, enable rotated session tickets.

recommendation.shortDescription: Evaluates whether the TLS server supports renegotiation.
Evaluates whether the TLS server supports renegotiation.

resultingRecommendation.shortDescription: Insecure renegotiation is enabled
resultingRecommendation.handlingRecommendation: Disable renegotiation or enable only secure renegotiation.

recommendation.shortDescription: Evaluates whether the TLS server supports secure renegotiation extension.

resultingRecommendation.shortDescription: Secure renegotiation extension is disabled
resultingRecommendation.handlingRecommendation: Consider to enable secure renegotiation extension.

recommendation.shortDescription: Evaluates whether the TLS server supports client-side secure renegotiation.
recommendation.detailedDescription: TLS secure renegotiation can be started by the client as well as by the server. In its configuration the server can restrict the support for the server-side secure renegotiation. In that case, only the server can start the renegotiation process.

recommendation.shortDescription: Evaluates whether the TLS server supports client-side secure renegotiation.
recommendation.detailedDescription: TLS secure renegotiation can be started by the client as well as by the server. In its configuration the server can restrict the support for the server-side secure renegotiation. In that case, only the server can start the renegotiation process.

recommendation.shortName: TLS Fallback Signaling Cipher Suite Value (SCSV) support
recommendation.shortDescription: Evaluates whether the TLS server supports TLS Fallback Signaling Cipher Suite Value (SCSV)
recommendation.detailedDescription: In order to establish the highest possible TLS version, TLS clients attempt to perform several TLS handshake starting with the one with the highest version. If a TLS handshake with a particular version does not work, the TLS client attempts to execute the handshake with a lower version. This of course allows an attacker to downgrade the TLS connection. TLS Fallback Signaling Cipher Suite Value (SCSV) was introduced to prevent downgrade attacks. For example, if a TLS client attempts to establish a TLS 1.1 connection after an unsuccessful TLS 1.2 handshake attempt, it includes a TLS SCSV cipher suite into the ClientHello message. The server accepts this handshake if and only if its highest version is TLS 1.1.

resultingRecommendation.shortDescription: TLS SCSV is disabled
resultingRecommendation.handlingRecommendation: Enable TLS Fallback Signaling Cipher Suite Value (SCSV)

recommendation.shortDescription: Evaluates whether the TLS server supports TLS compression

resultingRecommendation.shortDescription: TLS compression is supported
resultingRecommendation.handlingRecommendation: Disable TLS compression

recommendation.shortName: Moduli provided in FFDHE ServerKeyExchange messages are prime
recommendation.shortDescription: Evaluates whether the group moduli provided in FFDHE (finite field Diffie-Hellman ephemeral) ServerKeyExchange messages are prime

resultingRecommendation.shortDescription: DH group moduli are not prime
resultingRecommendation.handlingRecommendation: There is a critical vulnerability in your TLS implementation. Update your software or contact the developers.

recommendation.shortName: Moduli provided in FFDHE ServerKeyExchange messages are from common groups
recommendation.shortDescription: Evaluates whether the group moduli provided in FFDHE (finite field Diffie-Hellman ephemeral) ServerKeyExchange messages are from common groups defined by standardization bodies or RFCs

recommendation.shortName: Moduli provided in FFDHE ServerKeyExchange messages are safe primes
recommendation.shortDescription: Evaluates whether the group moduli provided in FFDHE (finite field Diffie-Hellman ephemeral) ServerKeyExchange messages are safe primes

resultingRecommendation.shortDescription: DH group moduli are not safe primes
resultingRecommendation.handlingRecommendation: There is a vulnerability in your TLS implementation. Update your software or contact the developers.

recommendation.shortDescription: Evaluates whether the TLS server requires the client to send a Server Name Indication (SNI) extension
Evaluated whether the server rejects unsupported ALPN Strings. This is important to mitigate the ALPACA attacks

resultingRecommendation.shortDescription: The TLS server does not reject unsupported ALPN Strings
resultingRecommendation.handlingRecommendation: If possible configure your server to use strict ALPN verification

recommendation.shortDescription: Evaluated whether the server rejects invalid SNI names. This is important to mitigate the ALPACA attacks

resultingRecommendation.shortDescription: The TLS server does not reject invalid SNI names.
resultingRecommendation.handlingRecommendation: If possible configure your server to use strict SNI verification

recommendation.shortDescription: Evaluated whether the server is vulnerable to ALPACA

resultingRecommendation.shortDescription: The TLS does not reject invalid SNI names.
resultingRecommendation.handlingRecommendation: If possible configure your server to use strict SNI and strict ALPN verification
